close_symbols: struct MemoryPool (definition and any function-pointer members / helpers used by pool APIs)
All callees (transitive) of MHD_pool_try_alloc / MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace / MHD_pool_reallocate / MHD_pool_allocate
explanation:
To prove absence of direct or indirect recursion you must examine every function the target calls and any functions they in turn call. Specifically:
- MHD_pool_try_alloc: called directly from the target; its implementation/callees must be checked to ensure they do not (directly or indirectly) call MHD_connection_alloc_memory_.
- MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace: called twice in the target; its implementation/callees must be checked for any path back to the target.
- MHD_pool_reallocate: called directly; its implementation/callees must be checked for recursive paths to the target.
- MHD_pool_allocate: called directly at the end; its implementation/callees must be checked for recursive paths to the target.
- mhd_assert: used in the function (may be a macro or a function). If it is a function (or expands to one), its implementation must be checked to ensure it does not call back to the target.
- struct MemoryPool (definition and any function-pointer members / helpers used by pool APIs): the pool APIs may invoke function pointers stored in the pool or helper routines; those pointers/helpers must be inspected because they could indirect-call the target.
- struct MHD_Connection (definition): the connection object may contain callbacks or pointers that pool code or other helpers could invoke; the struct layout is needed to discover such pointers.
- All callees (transitive) of the listed pool functions: to prove no indirect recursion you must include the full transitive call set reachable from the four pool-related functions above and inspect each for a path back to MHD_connection_alloc_memory_.

Include the implementations (or their symbols/callees) of the above so the next agent can build the transitive call graph and determine whether any call chain returns to MHD_connection_alloc_memory_, which would violate the MISRA rule.
